history.content: I could also try sending your question to the MEs who are EECS minors. I wonder whether they read this Piazza.

Hello, glad to see you are also taking this path. 

I also find the computational side of EECS to be incredibly fun and relevant to the MechE field and especially helpful in my current field of interest: digital twins and computational methods. I'm not in the research group, but I'd recommend looking at Tarek Zohdi's Multiphysics and Optimization Simulation Lab (MSOL) here at Berkeley to get a bit more insight into how computation can fit into interdisciplinary engineering research. 

I'm afraid you just missed Engineering 150, which was taught by Professor Zohdi this past fall (great class, highly recommend). Here's a GIF from my favorite project, which uses a machine learning algorithm to optimize an autonomous drone swarm for surveillance. 

best60fps.gif

I can't say for certain when E150 will next be offered. But there is still time to enroll in MEC201, which is a step up from E150. MEC201 covers far more advanced physics compared to E150. My experience in E150 involved making projects based on Dr. Zohdi's research papers (see MSOL link), and MEC201 will generally follow the same approach. Syllabus below (note E150 is not a prerequisite):

SYLLABUS-2022-MEC201-MSEC286-1.pdf

If I had more time, I would be taking MEC201 this semester. Unfortunately, I can't have everything. To fulfill my minor, I'm taking all my upper div EE courses this semester because COVID pushed back my plans. If I do end up accepted to the 5th Year Masters, then I will take this course myself. 

Sorry that this doesn't direct you toward any particular course in EECS, but I just wanted to talk about something that I thought would really interest you.

children.subject: Lots of people going down this route are robotics. MechE majors commonly take EECS classes like 128, 149, 192, 106A/B, 221A, 222. 128, 106A, 221A, 222 are cross listed as ME courses as well. EECS majors sometimes take ME 102B as well.

history.content:
Wondering if there are any MechEs here who have EECS minor advice? Is there a particular route (robotics VS algorithms VS circuits VS etc) you suggest that might be relevant for MechE? If its really individual-based, is there a particular field that might be more relevant in the future in EECS for MechEs?

Tbh, I'm not really sure what I want to do, but I have enjoyed coding so far (took 61a and in 61b rn), so the algorithmic side of EECS looks cool. Generally speaking, it looks like computation is becoming much more relevant in every field, so this is kinda why I'm interested in this side of EECS as well.

Any advice would be greatly appreciated.
history.subject: MechE major and EECS minor advice
